did.unittitle: Francis X. N. McGuire, O.S.A. records

bioghist.p: Father Francis Xavier McGuire (1909-2003) graduated from Villanova College in 1932. After graduation, he studied theology at the Gregorian University in Rome, was ordained to the priesthood in Rome in 1935, and earned his Doctorate of Divinity in 1939. That same year, he began teaching theology at Villanova College, and served as prefect of studies until 1941. During the Provincial Chapter of 1941, Father McGuire was appointed vice president of Villanova College and three years later, at age 34, became Villanova’s 24th president. While president of Villanova from 1944 to 1954, Father McGuire oversaw the transformation of Villanova College from a small liberal arts college to an expanded institution of higher education, culminating in Villanova’s elevation to University status in 1953. After leaving Villanova in 1954, Father McGuire taught at Merrimack College, in North Andover, Massachusetts, before continuing parochial ministries in parishes in Massachusetts and New York. His last active assignment was prior of the Retreat House, formerly Augustinian Academy, Staten Island, New York. He returned to Villanova in 1996, where he spent his remaining years.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Father Francis X. N. McGuire. The papers consist of correspondence, legal documents, news media, personal papers, and reports. The correspondence deals with academic accreditation, the National College Athletic Association, the Eastern College Athletic Conference, and the Division of Nursing. The NCAA materials relate to Villanova's qualifications under the NCAA's "Sanity Code," which governed the amount and forms of assistance offered to students on athletic scholarships. The legal documents mainly relate to loan agreements and estates (1949-1954), including the Eugene L. Garey estate. News media consists of newspaper clippings about Eugene L. Garey and about the installation of Father McGuire as president of the University. Personal papers include a sermon given by Father McGuire on the death of the Very Rev. Mortimer Sullivan and a copy of the Congressional Record in which is reprinted Father McGuire's sermon entitled “Peace and the Natural Law." Reports in the collection include Father McGuire's curriculum vitae and a report on development.
